Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Megawatt Electric Vehicle Superfast Charging Stations with Enhanced Grid Support Functionality as Energy Hubs

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Research Objectives and Approaches
The objective of this research is to investigate major technological challenges and develop novel technological solutions for next generation, superfast, energy efficient, and economic electric vehicle charging stations with high performance power grid support capabilities.

The approach is integrating and advancing novel power electronics, power system and control technologies to develop high power, low energy loss and high reliability power architectures and energy conversion units. The electric vehicle charging station will work as an energy hub where renewable energy sources, grid energy storage, electric vehicles and power grid exchange energies to simultaneously achieve superfast charging and grid supports.

Intellectual Merit
The proposed research activity develops critical technologies for power architectures, control and high efficiency medium-frequency transformer design for superfast electric vehicle charging and grid supports in the applications of electrification of transportations and renewable energy. The successful development of the proposed technologies will significantly improve energy conversion efficiency for electric vehicle charging and grid supports, increase system's reliability, and improve the electrical performance of charging and grid support infrastructures.

Broader Impacts
The proposed research reduces the energy cost and the infrastructure expense of electric grids, reduces greenhouse gas emission effects and facilitates the use of electric vehicles in our society. It aligns with the national strategies of the electrification of transportation and green energy. The research is integrated with education plans designed for underrepresented minority students, female students, high school students, university students and high school teachers from the university, local high schools and local communities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The proposed research and education tasks in this project have been accomplished.

On the research side, the research has led to 14 IEEE journal papers published in the most prestigious IEEE journals in power electronics: IEEE Transactions on Power Electronics, IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics and IEEE Journal of Emerging and Selected Topics in Power Electronics. There are 3 more IEEE journal papers are under review. Furthermore, numerous papers were published in various IEEE juried conferences.  The developed techniques also generated 10 issued or pending US / International patents which greatly help transfer the developed techniques to commercial products.

In the project, several novel modulation and optimal design techniques have been developed for a multifunctional high power electric vehicle (EV) charging station with cascaded multilevel inverter topology to achieve high performance and multifunction. The multifunctional EV charging station is integrated with renewable energy sources, energy storage, and the power grid. The multifunction includes EV charging and various grid support functions such as real power generation, reactive power compensation, grid voltage regulation, harmonic compensation, and load balancing, etc. These modulation techniques help to achieve high energy efficiency, fast charging and high performance. Several modeling techniques have been developed to characterize and improve the performance of passive components used in the power electronics systems. Techniques to reduce electromagnetic interference (EMI) were also developed to reduce the EMI generated from the switching of power electronics circuits. The developed techniques help greatly reduce EV charging infrastructure costs because a multifunction EV charging station can replace several single-function equipment on the grid. It is an all-in-one and win-win solution. These developed techniques have been successfully disseminated through IEEE conferences, journal publications, workshops, and seminars, etc.

The project brings positive impacts to electric vehicle charging networks with the developed optimal technical solution which can achieve low infrastructure cost, low operating expense, high performance, high reliability, and high energy efficiency. The techniques help transfer the electric vehicle charging, which was once considered as a burden to the power grid, to a good contributor to the power grid. The developed techniques can also improve life quality in our everyday life, help reduce greenhouse effects and improve our nation?s energy independence. 

On the education side, 8 Ph.D. and master students participated in project research activities. They have been trained to define, analyze and solve technical issues. They were also trained for technical communication and paper writing skills. Some of these students have graduated and they are successfully utilizing what they learned in the project to conduct research or develop products in both academia and industry. 11 high school students including 6 female and 7 underrepresented minority high school students have received learning and research training through the paid summer power electronics research internship. All of them are now successfully pursuing their college degrees in Universities.
